title: How serious is teenage love? - Quora

response.answer_text: Teen love and break ups can be very serious stuff. Teens want to believe with great certainty that they are adults. In fact, they are experiencing brain changes dramatically in how it is used and how it functions physiologically. It is a timeline. when many teens feel strong emotions. The most common reason for teens to develop depression and/or suicidal ideation, revolves around "breaking up." it is very common for the most healthy teen to feel a lot of angst on any given day. As teens develop and begin to differentiate a sense of self rather than echoing parental views, which is normal development, some teens can feel pretty desperate for a close relationship with any peer. It is the nature of teen relationships that each person is differentiating and growing differently. They don't yet understand that relationships will morph over time into a break up and then the building of new relationships. During the break up the emotions can run very high and people can feel strongly that: "I will never find anybody that will love me more than this person." It's one reason that teenage pregnancy is such a common complication of youthful dating. Both sexes are curious about how sexual intimacy works. There is a lot lot lot of peer pressure to not be a virgin. Problematically lack of experience and peer pressure contribute to early intimacy being tense. Most teens are not prepared for responsible sexual precautions. There are a lot of myths around ways to prevent pregnancy. (You can't get pregnant the first time. I'll pull out in time. Next time we'll be more ready. It won't matter just this once.) The only sex education quite a number of teens have is checking porn sites. This of course does not encourage an understanding of sensuality, pregnancy prevention, or an understanding of normality. Age 15 is the typical year that most young people have their first sexual experience. Therefore you can see that teen time periods are fraught with a lot of emotional naïveté. it is really important for parents to provide some actual and informed information about sexuality. You can giggle all you want both parent and child, but you need to be very specific about talking about body parts and what kinds of prevention you will help your child aquire. Shaming a teen will only result in them sneaking around. Better to be able to openly talk about it, even if you giggle, then to leave your teen with a void of information on a very important topic. No, many school systems do not teach anything about it anymore. It is not covered in biology class. It is not even covered in anatomy and physiology class. Mom and dad this is up to you. Many teens do not understand that the purpose of dating is to meet a variety of people and experience a number of personalities so that they can be discerning about their choice of a life partner. Your first teenage love is highly unlikely, but not impossibly, permanent. Parents need to be alert to provide competent information to your middle school, and certainly by the freshman year of high school. Other pieces of good information can include things like explaining how dating helps you sort and learn about how other people are. That getting stuck on one person early in life, will prevent a young person from developing their own list of traits they would be looking for in a permanent partner. Especially around the teen years. Remember the highly emotional state of teens and be alert for depression, giving away cherished items, or any implication that they can't live without ________.

Apart from most of the teenage couples that break up, patch up and break up every month or two, there are still a few couples that really try hard to make things work. For instance, let me tell you about my friend here. She and her partner completed three years together this November. Yes, they started as Nibba and Nibbi and even I was apprehensive about their relationship since it had engendered a few problems between their families. They had been studying in the same school for two and a half years. But after that their parents made them change their schools.  Now, the girl's parents are very strict, especially her mother. I wouldn't call her behavior compulsive or disturbing or anything, but yeah, it's complicated. So she doesn't get to use YouTube, phone, or anything. But yeah, she uses a small phone to talk to her boyfriend sometimes which her classmate gave her once to keep. So all communication that happens now between them is through this little phone. - Anyways, when the two individuals changed their schools, they obviously started facing some issues which couples in LDR usually do. Not meeting with each other physically, relying mostly on texts and calls, etc. My friend met a guy in her class who wasn't particularly attractive but who talked and behaved like my friend's boyfriend. He reminded her of him. And so she told me once, looking very tensed: “Ugh! I'm not sure! Yaar(friend), I'm very anxious. What if I start falling for this guy just cause of the distance. I won't, I know that. I can't, I know that. Still. I'm supremely worried.” I assured her everything is going to be alright. Her partner assured her he trusts her immensely and they both promised to each other they will make it work. They're still together and going strong. - So yes contrary to the popular belief, teenage love is indeed serious at times. It just depends on the two individuals, their will and efforts towards making the relationship work. ❤ *Image from Google

At the time very serious. A lot of teenagers (myself included) had crushes on girls both outside of school and in one case in my Form, although that was never going to last -:) However I did have a very serious desire for my best friend’s sister for a long time and to me that was very serious (in my mind), although looking back I hardly cuddled her -:) That said I have seen friends, and in particularly one of my sister’s friends who had a teenage love with a boy in the form when she was 14, and hey presto at the age of 21 they got married, and as far as I know still married. So at the time teenage love is very serious, and in any case teenage relationships vary from child and adult ones as attitudes change through the transition of teenage years, indeed early 20s. I have seen cases where very intensely involved late teenage years, (16–20) then suddenly go in different directions. Hopefully they haven’t married. I know at 16 (I had just left school) I was working with a girl who I had a very strong feeling for, but because I worked with her was caught in a double jeopardy and wasn’t sure how the employer would react. Indeed we did often walk home with her after work, and talk about the days work and sometimes my hand did fall in to hers but would suddenly let go as I didn’t want to feel that I was imposing myself. Actually I was very fond of her, but too frightened to say so. I left the bank and we went separate ways, but my feelings were still very strong. About three years later, I moved in to my own flat (where I still live) and remembered her address and wrote to her. We met up a few times and I invited her to dinner, as well as going to equine events (we both enjoyed horse shows and show-jumping). So in my mind I thought that she was aware of my feelings for her, even if I never penetrated her, and it really was a kiss and a cuddle and holding hands as we went around the events. Shock time came when I wrote to her to invite her for the whole weekend at the show as I had won a week end away in a competition and the hotel chain was just down the road from the event site. She had told me that she couldn’t go as she was going away that week end with her friend. Now she had a number of old school “girl” friends who she went away with, and she was also close to her sister and they went on weekends away, so I thought nothing of it. I knew that Patsy (in her own words) didn’t like her own company (being alone for long) so these weekends away seemed to make sense. A few weeks later I got a letter from her saying that she had a great time with this “Guy” ! It had never crossed my mind that she was dating another bloke; that is not to say that she had betrayed or “two timed” me, but she had never mentioned him before. To make things worse she told me that at the weekend he had proposed to her and they were indeed going to get married. It really did break my heart, and I did write to her telling her that I had loved her very much, but recognised that it was my fault for not saying, but though she knew. I did receive a reply to both letters and her last one I still have in a drawe with the photos we had at the horse shows when we were teenagers. There is rarely a day that goes by that her name doesn’t cross my mind or sometimes wonder whether she had children, indeed where she is. I have never tried to find out since I don’t want to be a catalyst for a divorce or friction in her marriage: I just genuinely hope that it did work out for her. So this shows that “teenage love” in mid-teens can be very serious and often does lead on to very long term relationships, even if in my case it went badly wrong.

Well, I’m a 16-year old guy, and I’m gonna explain this from the guy’s perspective. First, loving someone is love, regardless of age. So, onto the main point: When a guy falls in or crushes on a girl, she’s the most beautiful and precious person in your life. Sometimes, it gets so serious that your own family wouldn’t mean anything to you at the moment. Also, remember that hot girl you saw last week? What happened to her? She looks like a frog. NOBODY IS MORE BEAUTIFUL THAN MY (soon-to-be) QUEEN. you guys get the point, right? Also, if you know her on a certain personal level, and you meet her occasionally throughout the week, meeting her is the only thing you’ll look forward to. Also #2, Let’s say, she’s gone for a weeklong trip or something. You won’t see her for a week, but you’ll be able to DM her or something, right? Well, you’re wrong. Trust me, I’ve been through this a few times now. This is when you’ll understand what the terms ‘ dying to see you’ and ‘slowly dying from inside’ really mean. Oh boy, during the entire time she’s gone, you’ll suffer, and it’s gonna be a loooong time before you see her. Or at least that’s how it feels. Once you get to see her again, you’ll be the happiest guy in the entire known universe. The hardest part? It’s when she, for sure loves someone else (remember, she might not be dating you and it could be just you having a crush on her). You obviously hate that guy with all your heart, and you may even have an evil wish for him to get hit by a truck or something. But at the same time, you gotta respect him for being perfect enough to win her heart. If you truly love her, then you want what is the best for her. If going off with the other guy is what she wants, let her go because you really love her. Hehe, I think I got too serious

When you are a teenager in love this love is everything. All you want is time to be with him and everything else is something to endure, something to get through, something you put up with until you can be together again. I mean, finally. For a teenager what you want is to erase your otherness. We are one. It’s you and me, baby. You and me against the world. An adult has at the very least gained the faint notion that you and I are individuals, independent, and it’s precisely this sovereignty that will make our relationship viable. Adult relationships change you, but you are largely already you. Teenage relationships shape you. They take place during your formative years so create inexorable paths that you will continue to tread on years later. It’s in this way that teenage relationships all but seal your fate. I see now. I see now where this began. When you are a teenager you are more angst than answers, more dream than life, more in full contact with that dazzling, sacred core of you that is immortal. That guy you were with when you were a teenager will walk away with an understanding of you so true and so raw that no one else will ever again see you quite that clearly - not even you. You will lose your secret diaries, your lack of outlook, that particular vigor, the free-fall, your sky-dive, your fearlessness - and someone else will remember. It’s for all these reasons that I would consider teenage love as serious as a heart attack. Except that thanks to modern medicine, a heart attack is something you can recover from.

It can be. My very first real love, I was 16. I did not even actually date the dude. He was my good friend. He did not want to ruin our friendship. The feelings I had for him were indescribable. I was a sophomore, he was a senior. He would drive me home from school, and just around wherever. He loved me too, I just know he did. But he went to college in a different state. I followed suit, but went to a different college near his. By that time, I had a new boyfriend and eventually he got a new girlfriend. He ended up marrying that girlfriend. On my birthday. I tell ya, that was not an easy wedding to attend. I took a taxi outta there as soon as I was good and sauced up, probably about an hour into the reception. Maybe two hours. Maybe a half hour. It was the most pure love I had ever felt because up until the point of him telling me he just wanted to be friends, I had never been heartbroken. I had no fear of rejection up until that point (still not that I really give a shit now). When I told him I liked him, he bent down and kissed me for about 5 minutes. Told me we would talk tomorrow about what we would be. He never came around. I went on vacation for a week with my family, and when I got back he had only IMed me that he did not want to ruin our friendship. I waited, and waited, and waited. When I got my first boyfriend, I told my first love before “I love you. I am head over heels, over the moon, crazy in love with you.” He still wanted to be friends. Therefore, I agreed to date my boyfriend.

Just about as “serious” as any other kind of love. It should be noted, however, that teens are more likely to be like manic people, so they will have more extreme feelings over a shorter period of time, but these feelings feel real to them and should not be dismissed as that then dismisses the person feeling them. Just know that manic people don’t tend to stay in love very long. Hot fires burn out quickly. This shortness of interest, does not mean that the feelings are not “serious” though. Many people are like this (manic love/infatuation), they just don’t have their parents myopically watching every thing they do. The main thing is to make sure everyone uses protection: Rubbers (disease prevention, birth control) and birth control pills. As long as no diseases are contracted and no pregnancies are created, teenagers can move on freely and go about their manic shenanigans no harm no foul. And eventually, barring bad genetics, they will become emotionally mature and encounter serious and long lasting non manic love. But until then, do not discount their feelings… And… DON’T BE WEIRD AND ILLOGICALLY “MORAL” AND RELIGIOUS AND STUPID! ALWAYS MAKE SURE TEENS USE PROTECTION!! ALWAYS!!! Crazy manic people need protection the most of all of us.

If only we could bottle up the energy teens put into their love we could make a fortune. How serious is it - - for some teens it is deadly serious. Check the stats on teenage suicide and see how many died due to relationship problems - either with friends, girl friends or parents. Teens have only hot or cold - they do not understand lukewarm. Everything is to the extreme - so when a rupture occurs in their lives they have no middle ground on which to stand - it’s all or nothing in their immature minds. When counseling American teens in the High School in Bangkok, Thailand I was shocked to learn how often teens thought of suicide. Since I was a “green” counselor I went to my supervisor and reported my find-ings and he confirmed that he was getting the same data/results. These were affluent, well behaved teens who had a lot going for them …. fortunately only one attempted suicide while I was there, and survived. All in all Davidson, I would have to say that we owe it to our teens to take THEM very seriously. Emotions to the wall notwithstanding, we must work to stay in touch with our young people, even when they push us away. Stand in the shadows if you must, but don’t abandon them. They are priceless. Thank you.

Everybody takes love so seriously. Like it is this sacred thing that nobody should touch unless they’re willing to die for it. Teenagers often do not feel like this. They experiment. They are dead serious about love one week. Like their significant other is everything to them. Like they wouldn’t see the point of living if it weren’t for them. It may very well be serious in this moment. Then, the next week, they break up and hate each other’s guts and they are jsut as serious about that as about the mutual love they shared before. After some time, the feelings fade, they go back to their normal routine, or meet someone new, and eventually forget about that other person, it becomes just another memory. They realize they weren’t serious about it in the first place. We make bad choices. We associate with shitty people. We start relationships that are bound to fail because the only thing that holds us together is a warped, romanticized idea of a very common feeling. But that’s okay. It’s a part of growing up.

Teenage love can be very intense and very serious. Especially if sex is involved. A lot of people have been killed because teenagers were having sex and they tried to stop them. However, extremely intense relationships tend to burn themselves out. In the old days, parents and grown-ups in general tended to scoff at “puppy love” and in many cases they were right to do so. But there may have been some envy involved because they new that they would never again feel that intense passion. If I were dealing with two teenagers who said they were in love, I would make sure the girl was on birth control, but other than that I would let nature take it’s course rather than intervene. Unless, there were really good reasons for doing so. For instance, if I had a teenage daughter who claimed to be in love with some thug who as a teenager already had a rap sheet, I would intervene for her own protection. She might hate me for it at the time, but someday she would grow up and realize that I might have saved her life. I would also intervene if he was a user or purveyor of illegal substances.

I believe most of the time they are not really ready for it, and don’t understand what they are getting involved in, and what it takes to make it work, and they are really not ready for how they will feel when they break up. They sometimes regret it later. I fell in love with my first love and the only person I ever shared deep mutual love with when I was 15. I don’t know that I was really ready for it, or understood it. I definitely didn’t fully appreciate the relationship, or what it took to make it work…when we broke up I attempted suicide (even though the reason we broke up was because I betrayed her WITH her best friend…and I guess I was upset enough that I thought she should have seen me betray her and see me die on the on the same day). How ready do you think we felt for that breakup? How would she have felt if I died? Do either of us regret it? NO, we both treasure that time together. I wouldn’t trade that time together with her for anything I have seen or experieced from then until now. Were we actually really in love? You can bet on it, it was as real as it gets. We were just talking about it recently, 37 years later. But I promise you the odds of that conversation happening were very low; the odds of me dying in that suicide attempt were higher…and it probably would have scarred her for life. Be careful when you are betting on those kinds of odds. We did get back together more than 5 years later, fell in love all over again and got engaged but never married. Didn’t talk for a very long time after that 2nd breakup. We are friends again now…and she is 100% supportive of me transitioning, and she follows on Quora. I gaurantee you we beat the odds on those things too.

There was this guy whom I was crushing on since last 2–3 months. If I would stumble in front of him then I would blame myself the entire day for that. After a while I sent him a friend request. ‘Teen love’ you know! So this is how are conversation went - He - “Hey!” Inner Me - “Damn! He messaged you first. That’s a sign Bhawna ;) Congrats! Now message - “Hiiiiiiiii” Me - “hi” He - “How do you know me? Never saw you before.” Me-   We ended up being ‘just friends’. I felt bad for the first day but later on I couldn’t care less about him. So how serious is teenage love! In my personal opinion leaving some special exceptions aside it isn’t serious at all. It can be termed as mere attraction not love.  Namaste!

Well, it all depends on couple themselves. I have seen many kind of relationships , some were serious , some just for timepass… Some fall apart while some are still going strong. I would give you some of the examples: Firstly, the boy and girl met in class 9th . Both of them come from diff. school and came into relationship in first 2 months itself.Even after diff. streams in class 11th , they were pretty strong. They broke off after 1 year of leaving school.Maybe due to religious differences or due to diff. College timings.Second, the boy was studying in the same school from the past few years and girl came up in 11th standard. Their relationship started within one week and died as soon as school ends.Third one ,girl was in school and boy in college and they were in relationship for about 1 and half years and ended before girl’s board exam started.Fourth one, girl and boy met in class 11th and started as friends which gradually convert to relationship and going pretty strong.And there are many more diff. examples, will gonna add soon.Thankyou. Edits are welcome.

“How serious is teenage love?” Not clear what you mean, so I will guess. Regardless of the AGE of the person involved, a sense of “love” can appear to them and to others to be “serious,” when it is actually more accurately described as a short term, or even a self-delusion based infatuation. Since younger people are more likely to guess incorrectly that they are “seriously in love,” many people have ERRONEOUSLY concluded that ALL teen age emotions should be essentially laughed off. But since things which happen at that age, can result in anything from minor disruption to people’s lives, to permanent distortion of them, to extreme anti-social acts (including suicide and murder), I tend to take teenage love seriously as AN EVENT, at least.

Really serious provided you both consider it to be… bare in mind that a very few amount of people meet their 2nd halves during teenage love (really few…) and hence it’s encouraged to take it at a considerable level of seriousness. the result will eventually be you (both…surely) enjoying yourselves and if you’re active enough, you’ll get to discover a lot …lot of things in this life. in a nutshell; Love is love (tho often considered that teenage love is barely attraction…duh) it’s still special so enjoy it. hope it helps :)

The age is never a boundary in any aspect yeah I know the first line after the title seems contradictory anyways leave it I think the perfect age would be after teenage because in most of the cases the relationship turns out to be reason for distraction because it is the age where you have to focus on your studies or career and I think it's unfortunate if you fall in the true love at this age because most of the case is the relationship turn in to disaster still it's not the case. 95 percentage of its attraction created due to secretion of several hormones in the human body and surrounding environment and many such more things and this attraction is always a disaster in most of the cases it takes most of the times to enjoy the moments so-called couple goals and when they are not able to have communication due to any of the circumstances it affects both or one of the another. Google has quite a good analytics and I think I also have some good reason why not to fall in relationship in teenage it's normal it happens but if you have the option to come out from that just be out I am assuring you that you will not regret and I am assuring one more thing that you will regret if you don't come out So continuing For more click----> Blog | iiw-Ã

Teenage love is not serious—it's downright scary. Teens fall in what they think is love. Unfortunately. It is driven by hormones instead of logic. They don't look down the road to see consequences of whatever drastic action their fantasy presents. Parents, especially these days, face the horrors of the children they spoI led such as threats of running away, pregnancy and sense of entitlement. This doesn't include not finishing their education. To make matters worse, parents also may face raising their grandchildren. I would say that teenage love can be downright scary. Of course, it depends on the teenager. Some are more logical than others. How did you raise yours?

Define “serious.” I was a teenager who was deeply in love with a girl. But of course, I’m a bit more intense in the complexity of my feelings. I’m a bit of an emotional misfit. Hormones can impel you to do otherwise irrational things. We are slaves to our emotions. So, teenage love (or infatuation) can be very serious indeed. You look older based on your avatar. So, I’m guess you have a young daughter or niece (or son, etc.) who is involved with another young person. Don’t attempt squash this relationship or else you’ll just trigger rebellion — and this could be even worse. Attempting to completely forbid a relationship will likely lead to a disaster.

Before three years: He: I love you Shona! She: I love you, baby. Now: He: I love you so much. You mean life to me. She: I love you loads! Nothing has changed. The love, the passion, the care are the same but just Shona and baby are changed! He found another Shona and she found a baby again! ~Srilekha

If they are having sex then very serious for some. That is why the campaign to suggest that sex is t a big deal is pretty stupid. Keep your kids sex free as long as you can. Have good conversations with them around the binding issues that happen when you have sex. Between the rush of all the good feelings it creates a false sense of love.

Every time you see him you fall in love with him. Your heart beats fast when he talks to you. You can't express to him but deep inside you love him. When you listen to songs (romantic) you remember him as if the song is made for you both. You feel jealous when he talks to/about another girl. You die to see him on every moment of your life. You remember him while you sleep. He everyday comes on your dream. Unknowingly you become a shayar.  Teenage love is the most purest form of love and can't match with any of the feeling in this world. Suggestions are always welcomed. Yours, Prachi Khetan.

Pretty serious. My husband and I fell in love the day we met. We were 14. Started datinga couple months later when we were both 15. We got married when we were both 17. No we didn’t get married because of pregnancy( I have infertility problems). We have been together almost four years now. We are still happy and in love. We don’t see our relationship ever ending. We have never broken up or taken any type of breaks in our relationship.

You know, just the other day I was saying on another answer that middle school dating only lasts a couple months or so. High school might last a year or so. Few people marry the people they date in highschool, and many of those who marry end up in divorce. Teenagers are immature and full of hormones. That’s not to say some teenage relationships are not meaningful. But not advisable to take it too seriously.

teenage love can be very serious. It depends on the people. Our hearts do not know age like our brains do. Think of it this way… you can love a dog or a cat the same way at 14 as you can as an adult. As an adult we just realize a lot more. Most of the time teenage love doesn’t last because as we grow into adulthood our lives change drastically. We go to college, start careers, ect.

Well, the girl I fell in love with met her bf in high school and they have been dating for around 4 years now…..so from my perspective I’d say it can be pretty freaking real…….. Sorry. Just in pain with no one to talk to.

..I personally don't believe its lt's true love. They make think they are in love but for simple reasons such as: They like the same music, same hangout places, same ideas about life and such! True love is loving this person for real, establishing a love routine, making long term decisions, the more serious life roles. I thought I fell in love in grade 5, was his girlfriend till grade 10, no sex yet. He moved away in grade 11 and missed him. Went to visit him just outa highschool, we had sex but wasn't true sex. Then yrs down the road when I was 38, I visited him again. I was happy we were still friends and that he was happy yo hear from me. I never had sex with him this time and I could tell he was upset with me. Now he and i barely contact each other anymore. Thete that's my story lol

Thanks for the A2A. It’s very serious to the teenagers who experience it. Whether or not it grows as they do varies greatly, but even if it dies out completely, that doesn’t make it unimportant while it lasts.

Varies from person to person. Usually, these are first time affairs which are trials to experiment on recent learning. These tend to be less spiritual and natural. They lean toward passion which is temporary. Such liaisons are experimental and a way of learning practically about life.
It can be the beast love my soulmate was from High school we have different Karmic paths
